text: Django, a popular python webframework.
http://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/releases/1.2-alpha-1/#what-you-can-do-to-help
There are tons of libraries and apps needing conversion from versions 2.x to 3.1.
Pick one and have a go at it.
Try twisted, it might be suitable with your current background and should be really challenging as well.
You can try mercurial.
You will learn about writing performant python application that can run on windows and *nix system.
I am (the only) author of two: Chestnut package manager and Wavemol.
If you are interested...
I like http://trac.edgewall.org
Any.
Although what you should mainly be looking for are:

If I'm going to recommend something that both needs help, is worthy of help, and interesting for many, I'd say Moovida, which although run by commercial interests it is open source, written in Python and looking good, but definitely not really up to scratch yet compared to for example XBMC.
Pygame is in the process of completing its next major version which is a huge rewrite of the previous.
iPython has recently undergone a major architectural change.
Many features (like context sensitive auto completer) are yet to be implemented for the new architecture.
The team is awesome and welcoming as well.
It's not really hard; plus you have the old code that you can reference to find how they implemented it earlier.
Just port and change to the new API(that is obviously better), and have fun!
If you're an ex-SA with some time to spare, please, please, pretty please, join the Cobbler developers.
It's python, it uses Django (which I like a lot) and it's all about helping other fellow SAs!
There are so many different things to do there, you can either contribute to the core, or write adaptors to interact with other products (Chef for example).

Good thing about it is that it's half programming and half SA project, so you'll feel at home there and unlike just a regular dev most of the problems that this tool tries to solve will be familiar to yourself.
Thousand Parsec!
If I recall correctly the GEOS python bindings are unmaintained, so that's a nice (smallish) project you could jump into I suppose.
Really nice if you're into geospatial stuff (be aware that there's also shapely on top of the C GEOS library).
If you'd like to improve your python, Bazaar VCS has a number of experienced python developers hacking on it, and I think they generally have a good code-review system.
It's also a good example of how to write performant python.
